The Baltimore Symphony will present the first of this year's concerts at Hopkins in
Shriver Hall at four o'clock on Sunday afternoon. The featured soloist will be the talented
young pianist Lorin Hollander who will play Tschaikovsky's Piano Concerto Number One in
B Flat Minor.
The orchestra will play Haydn's Symphony Number 104 and Prokofieff's Lieutenant

Sunday's concert is the first in a series of two which the Baltimore Symphony will
present at Hopkins in 1962. The next appear ance of the symphony at Shriver will be on
March 11.
Lorin Hollander, the piano soloist, has received widespread critical acclaim for his control over his instrument and the force and power of his performance. Although still in his
teens, he has appeared in major concerts in New York and San Antonio, cut several
popular records, and appeared on television.
Hollander first came to prominence when he appeared as a last minute replacement for
Van Cliburn in a concert in San Antonio in 1959. He was heralded following this performance for his "dazzling display of virtuosity." Following this triumph he scored a hit in his
appearance on the Perry Como Show.
The New York press applauded Hollander as a brilliant performer following his concert
in Carnegie Hall with the Detroit Symphony. He was hailed as "one of the chief adornments
of the next generation of American Pianists," with "an incredible gift for music making."
The appearance in Baltimore will be one stop on a tour in which Hollander will appear
with the New York Philharmonic, the National Symphony and the Milwaukee Symphony.
In Sunday's concert the Baltimore Symphony will be conducted by Peter Herman
Adler.

Radio station WJHU, the student-run AM station,
Las been broadcasting to a limited audience for many
years now. The station's programming, although of varying quality and regularity, has been a refreshing addition to the cacaphony of the AM band and the triteness
of much of the FM band.
However, 850 kc has a disappointingly small istenIng audience. The station is receivable only on radio sets
in the Homewood dormitories and the Bradford Apartments, which are specially wired for reception. Beyond
these three buildings, WJHU is unknown. Hence, considering that only a small percentage of the Hopkins
community lives in these buildings, the station serves
only a small part of its potential audience.
Most large universities (and many small colleges)
Support and operate semi-professional FM radio stations.
The programming is of high quality—fine music, discussion, drama, news, etc. These stations serve both the
university community and the general radio audience in
the locality of the school.
Certainly this is a feasible and likely activity for
This university to engage in. The Baltimore Junior College, an institution of considerably less repute anti financial resources, has had an excellent FM station for

WJHU-FM would serve the community and benefit the
university. The Public Relations Office might be willing to combine with present staff of WJHU to bring

The current situation of student government on the
Hopkins campus appears to be perilously close to that
of so many other schools where student government is
in the process of disintegration. As was pointed out in
the February 4 edition of the New York Times there is
a national trend of disinterest in student government
on the college campus.

Columbia College the student body overwhelmingly
voted to disband all student government. At Brown University the president of the student court initiated action

University of Connecticut has become embroiled in a
struggle to maintain itself and its power.

From 1946-59 he was a bacteriologist at the Harvard Medical

Japanese occupation.
Dr. Hanks received his undergraduate education at Allegheny
College (Pa.) and his Ph.D. degree from Yale University. He
also held a National Research
Council fellowship at Harvard
University.
From 1932 to 1939, Dr. Hanks
was assistant professor of bacteriology at the George Washington University Medical School.
He then joined the staff of the
Leonard Wood Memorial Foundation, first as a bacteriologist,
and later, as director of the
Foundation's research laboratory,
the position he now holds.
Currently, Dr. Hanks serves
as a consultant to the U.S. Public Health Service and is a member of several professional societies, including the American
Society for Microbiology, the
American Association of Immunologists, the Society for Experimental Biology, the Tissue
Culture Association, and the
International Leprosy Association.
His principal research interests have centered on bacteriological investigations in leprosy
and the study of tissue cultures,
the mechanisms of the tuberculin-type of allergy, and the
metalbolism and cytology (study
of structure and functions) of
mycobacteria (slender, rod-like
bacteria which have been found
to cause leprosy, tuberclosis.

A new round of Peace Corps

8:30 A.M. February 17th in centers throughout the country.
Among the many fields providing opportunities for Peace
Corps service are
teaching,
nursing, engineering, plumbing,
carpentry, agriculture, medicine,
home economics, architecture,
city planning, geology, physical
education.
While some of the projects
call for technical skills, many
others require men and women
without such formal or specialized training. Among these are
liberal arts graduates for community development projects and
people with general farming
backgrounds.
"No one should automatically
exclude himself from consideration because he considers himself either too highly skilled or
not skilled enough," Peace Corps
Director Sargent Shriver said in
announcing the tests. "We will
match qualifications to the growing requests we are reciving from
abroad."
The minimum age for applicants is 18; there is no maximum.

A coach's duties are to instill a team feeling into a
group of individuals. He must fit various styles of play into

Dickinson Won Last Year
Dickinson's Red Raiders, Hopkin's foe tomorrow afternoon,
was one of two teams to defeat
the Jays last season, coming out
on top of a 23-9 score.
Coach Mickey Cochrane figured on a rough season before
his first match, even without the
rash of injuries that has beset
Hopkins. Both co-captains are
out with injuries. Don Haynie,
who wrestles at 130 pounds has
had a sore shoulder for most of
the season. Jim Weathersbee will
wrestle in Haynie's place tomorrow.
Ward Still Out
Co-captain Buff Ward, (167)
has been troubled with a knee injury, suffered while playing on
the football team throughout the
season. Ward has less trouble
once he gets his opponent down
when he can work from knees,
so that his injury is not jarred.
"Ward and Haynie must both
remain day-to-day propositions,"
according to Cochrane.
Bill Beck now looms as Ward's
replacement, with Cochrane still
having trouble filling the middle
classes.
